earliestArticle.dc:abstract: Autosomal recessive cerebellar ataxias are a group of rare disorders that share progressive degeneration of the cerebellum and associated tracts as the main hallmark. Here, we report two unrelated patients with a new subtype of autosomal recessive cerebellar ataxia caused by biallelic, gene-disruptive mutations in GDAP2, a gene previously not implicated in disease. Both patients had onset of ataxia in the fourth decade. Other features included progressive spasticity and dementia. Neuropathological examination showed degenerative changes in the cerebellum, olive inferior, thalamus, substantia nigra, and pyramidal tracts, as well as tau pathology in the hippocampus and amygdala. To provide further evidence for a causative role of GDAP2 mutations in autosomal recessive cerebellar ataxia pathophysiology, its orthologous gene was investigated in the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster. Ubiquitous knockdown of Drosophila Gdap2 resulted in shortened lifespan and motor behaviour anomalies such as righting defects, reduced and uncoordinated walking behaviour, and compromised flight. Gdap2 expression levels responded to stress treatments in control flies, and Gdap2 knockdown flies showed increased sensitivity to deleterious effects of stressors such as reactive oxygen species and nutrient deprivation. Thus, Gdap2 knockdown in Drosophila and GDAP2 loss-of-function mutations in humans lead to locomotor phenotypes, which may be mediated by altered responses to cellular stress.
earliestArticle.dc:creator: Eidhof I
earliestArticle.dc:title: GDAP2 mutations implicate susceptibility to cellular stress in a new form of cerebellar ataxia.

evidence.dc:description: Gdap2 knockdown Drosophila exhibited motor phenotypes such as righting defects, uncoordinated walking behavior, inability to fly, reduced walking distance and speed.
evidence.rdfs:label: Gdap2 Drosophila Knockdown

evidence.detectionMethod: WES with Sanger confirmation and co-segregation analysis. Genetic testing for spinocerebellar ataxias (SCAs) 1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 12, 17 and dentatorubral-pallidoluysian atrophy (DRPLA) were negative.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Difficulty writing, Increase in bilateral knee reflexes
evidence.previousTestingDescription: His clinical examination displayed cerebellar ataxia with abnormal finger-to-nose and heel-knee-shin tests. Bilateral knee reflexes were symmetrical increased (+++) and Babinski signs were negative. Cranial nerves, muscle strength and sensory examinations were normal. Mild cognitive decline with a Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) of 24/30, a Scale for the Assessment and Rating of Ataxia (SARA) score of 17.5/40 and International Cooperative Ataxia Rating Scale (ICARS) score of 46/100. Brain MRI revealed cerebellar atrophy.

dc:source.dc:creator: Dong HL
dc:source.dc:title: Novel GDAP2 pathogenic variants cause autosomal recessive spinocerebellar ataxia-27 (SCAR27) in a Chinese family.

evidence.rdfs:label: Dong Proband

evidence.detectionMethod: Exome sequencing with Sanger sequencing for confirmation and segregation analysis. No obvious variants in known ataxia genes were observed. Reported variants were filtered for variant type, rarity (MAF <0.5%) and conservation (>0.75, phyloP). Parental DNA for Patient AW not available.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Speech problems, jerky eye movements, dysexecutive syndrome, bed ridden
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Brain MRI at age 53 years revealed severe atrophy of the cerebellum, both vermian and hemispheric, mainly of the superior aspect, and also global cerebral atrophy (cortical and central). Levels of alpha-fetoprotein, vitamin E, copper, and folic acid were normal. Screening for trinucleotide repeat expansions was negative for SCAs 1, 2, 3, 6, 7, 8, 10, 12, and 17, and for Friedreichâ€™s ataxia. Normal nerve conduction studies. Normal opthalmological evaluation. Post-mortem brain examination revealed severe cerebellar atrophy in combination with a mild atrophy of the pes pontis.
evidence.rdfs:label: Patient AW

evidence.detectionMethod: Exome sequencing. Sanger sequencing was performed for confirmation of the variants and for segregation analyses using standard techniques. No obvious variants in known ataxia genes were observed. Variants were filtered for variant type, rarirty (MAF <0.5%) and conservation (>0.75, phyloP). Paternal DNA unavailable.
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: Difficulty writing, cerebellar dysarthria, downgoing plantar responses, ataxia on finger chase and heel-shin slide, Mild spastic paraplegia Cervical dystonia
evidence.previousTestingDescription: No weakness. Normal sensory examination. An MRI brain scan revealed mild cerebellar atrophy. Ophthalmological examinations were normal. Nerve conduction studies and EMG did not show evidence of a peripheral neuropathy. Laboratory testing including vitamin E, metabolic screening, albumin, cholesterol, alpha-fetoprotein, lactate, acanthocytes, copper, ceruloplasmin, and coeliac screen was normal or negative. Genetic testing for Friedreich, spinocerebellar ataxias (SCAs) 1, 2, 3, 6, 12, 14 and 17, dentatorubral-pallidoluysian atrophy, autosomal recessive spastic ataxia of Charlevoix-Saguenay and SPG7 were negative.
evidence.rdfs:label: Patient NIJ

evidence.previousTestingDescription: Neuropsychological assessment revealed widespread deficits in encoding, learning, and consolidating new verbal information. Overall, the patient exhibited prominent deficits in episodic memory, verbal working memory, and executive functions. A brain MRI scan, including susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI), performed showed marked cerebellar atrophy affecting the hemispheres and more significantly the vermis, as well as mild cortical atrophy, midbrain and pons atrophy. Nerve conduction studies (NCS), electromyography (EMG) and ophthalmological evaluation were all normal. Laboratory testing of alpha-fetoprotein levels, vitamin E, copper, and folic acid were also normal. Testing for various markers (a panel of paraneoplastic markers of autoimmunity, GAD, NMDA, AMPA, GABAB, DPPX and VGKC, as well as monkey cerebellum frozen tissue) were negative.

dc:source.dc:creator: Breza M
dc:source.dc:title: A homozygous GDAP2 loss-of-function variant in a patient with adult-onset cerebellar ataxia.

evidence.rdfs:label: Breza Proband

dc:description: *GDAP2* was first reported in relation to autosomal recessive spinocerebellar ataxia in 2018 (Eidhof et al., PMID: 30084953) in which two female patients presented with late onset gait ataxia, speech changes, cognitive impairment, spasticity, and cerebellar atrophy and were found to have biallelic null variants in the GDAP2 gene. Variants in this gene have been reported in at least four probands in three publications (PMIDs: 30084953, 32437512, 32428220). The mechanism of pathogenicity is reported to be loss of function as the probands affected with cerebellar ataxia all have biallelic nonsense or frameshift variants in *GDAP2*. This gene-disease relationship is also supported by an animal model study by Eidhof et al. in which knockdown of the Gdap2 gene in *Drosophila* flies caused abnormal motor behavior, decreased the life span of mutant flies, and increased susceptibility to oxidative stress and starvation (PMID: 30084953). In summary, there is strong evidence to support the relationship between *GDAP2* and autosomal recessive spinocerebellar ataxia. Three years must elapse from the first proposal of the assertion to reach a definitive classification without any valid contradictory evidence. We will re-evaluate this gene-disease relationship at that time to determine if an upgraded classification of definitive is warranted. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Cerebellar Ataxia GCEP on the meeting date December 11, 2024 (SOP Version 11).
